thread.title: A looming rate hike weighs on gold
thread.title_full: A looming rate hike weighs on gold - MarketWatch

author: By     Mark DeCambre
title: A looming rate hike weighs on gold
text:
Gold futures ticked lower in early trade Wednesday trade as the prospect of a September interest-rate hike comes closer into view.
The yellow metal also took cues from a employment report from Automatic Data Processing that showed that the private sector added 185,000 jobs in July. That was a slower pace than in June, but perhaps not slow enough to give the Federal Reserve pause as it considers lifting key interest rates for the first time since 2006.
Gold futures inched lower after the ADP report was released at 8:15 a.m. Eastern Time.
December gold GCZ5, -0.63% is off $2, or down 0.2%, at 1,088.60 an ounce after settling at $1,090.70 on Tuesday.
September silver is on a winning streak, gaining 2 cents, or 0.1%, to trade at $14.58 an ounce, after closing up 0.3% on Tuesday at $14.56 an ounce.
Gold came under pressure after Dennis Lockhart, the president of the Atlanta Fed, said he supports a interest-rate hike as soon as the Federal Reserve’s next policy meeting in September, speaking in an interview with The Wall Street Journal. His comments came late Tuesday, just before the yellow metal closed for trading in the afternoon, and follow those of St. Louis Fed President James Bullard, who also saw a hike next month.
A rate rise is likely to weigh on buyers of dollar-denominated commodities like gold. Higher rates increase the return on dollar deposits, which makes them more appealing to traders. But increased rates diminish the appeal of gold, which doesn’t offer any interest.
The ICE U.S. Dollar Index DXY, +0.16% a measure of the buck against rival currencies, was lower at 97.7340, or off 0.2%, from its levels in late Tuesday trade, but still relatively strong.
“The dollar trending higher has clearly been one of gold’s key obstacles of late, as Fed rate-hike expectations increasingly converge towards the September [Federal Open Market Committee] meeting,” said UBS analysts Edel Tully and Joni Teves in a Wednesday research note.
Stock-index futures jumped in premarket trade after the ADP report, suggest a strong open to the stock market. That could detract from gold, which typical gains momentum as buyers seek safe assets.
In other metals, October platinum PLV5, -0.96% lost $2.80, or 0.3%, to trade at $955.20 an ounce, after finishing at 958.50 an ounce Tuesday, while palladium PAV5, -0.76% gave up $1.80, or 0.3%, $596.80 an ounce.
High-grade copper HGU5, -0.66% was little changed at $2.36 a pound.
